movie_review_blurb: More relatable than its predecessor but no more spell-binding, Justice League races through its paces and ends: four hours of exposition and posturing stuffed in a two-hour package.

... writer-director Ron Shelton is a long way from the cerebral wit of his Bull Durham heyday.

... not an easy film to forget or ignore.

movie_review_blurb: If only this movie were as smart as its inspiration.

With unsympathetic leads, a clunky script and timeworn themes, Valerian stands and falls on the strength of its visual elements and action set-pieces -- which are, yes, pretty weird, and occasionally downright marvelous.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director David F. Sandberg (Lights Out) milks maximum chills from the material and his actors, though he can't overcome a script in which people repeatedly do stupid things for no reason.
While it's overlong and sometimes disjointed, this heist flick delivers genuinely likable characters, winning performances and solid laughs.

By turns funny, uplifting and a little queasy-making, the film sustains that tension for a while - before, ultimately, taking a too-predictable route.

The film doesn't offer any kind of soothing balm for our troubled times. What it does offer is a powerful affirmation of its characters' complex humanity.
A scripted drama with the unflinching, unjudging eye of a documentary...
The story hits plenty of familiar beats, yet its setting and the actors' conviction combine to give it a feel-good freshness.
The film doesn't glamorize the misadventures of its heroine any more than it condemns them, and the result is fresh in every sense.

movie_review_blurb: For each deliriously silly action sequence, Refueled offers long scenes of tired genre conventions played straight.

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers have created a movie which is didactic, yet not condescending, and inspirational without being corny.
In the end, the treatment of women and the actions of the fundamentalist gangsters give the film an oppressive air, so much so that even the music is no longer transcendent.
Into My Heart doesn't get into your heart. It's too stagey and too cynical.
Gathering these various gleaners into the pastiche that is her film, Varda preserves them, gives them new form, and therefore new life.
When you're not admiring the cinematography or the excellent score, you're kept smiling by the slightly off center inhabitants of Villaserena.
The film's plot, fashioned after an American western, is disappointing and predictable.
An entertaining breakthrough film that puts Indian faces on the screen.
A collection of small, heroic acts that lead the characters and the audience to a greater knowledge of yet another injustice.
Regardless of its flaws, On Hostile Ground makes an important statement about the dangers abortion providers and their families continue to face.
A touching, intimate portrayal of how women cope in this closed society.
It isn't earth-shattering, but, like Veber's film, it disturbs our complacency.
Actors move as though they were confined to a small space, hindering their expressive ability.
movie_title: The Young Girl and the Monsoon (2001)

movie_review_blurb: If Town & Country were a play, it would already have closed.
[Bouajila] gives a charming performance.
Gardos' film turns a poignant tale of displacement into melodrama.
It is the Nazi's eyes and his demeanor that keep you riveted to the screen.
Sinks under the weight of too many details.
Its subject matter couldn't be more topical.
In Pizzicata, [Winspeare] fashions [the Salentine dances] into a language through which we come to understand not only the characters but the sway of life
The Skylers' collaboration is nothing short of a 21st-century version of Rebel Without a Cause.
Technology just cannot recreate the excitement of live performance.
movie_title: Cirque du Soleil: Journey of Man (2000)

movie_review_blurb: There is enough unbroken time with Swinton's Ada to make watching Conceiving Ada worthwhile.
The flawless progress of this documentary lies in the filmmakers' unwavering fealty to their subjects.
An accomplished debut.
Writer-director Feo Aladag's powerful debut film about a Turkish woman fleeing her husband evokes a modern-day Greek tragedy.
Talented young director Pablo Trapero is undermined by a weak screenplay for this story of organized crime in Argentina.
A documentary about the demise of the filmmaker's village in Spain, The Sky Turns is poorly conceived but pleasing to look at.

Those of us who began our romance with the movies when double features were preceded by cartoons will revel in some of the outstanding animated shorts nominated this year by the Motion Picture Academy.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This year's Oscar-nominated documentary short films (shown theatrically in two separate programs) lack the journalistic integrity one would expect in this category.
Na Wewe from Belgium and Wish 143 from the U.K. are the standouts in an otherwise lackluster group of Oscar-nominated live-action shorts.
This excellent debut film provides an insider's view of life in Kashmir.
Abbas Kiarostami deconstructs the cinematic art form in this cerebral but dialogue-heavy film featuring a luminous Juliette Binoche.
A beautifully photographed tale of betrayal, A Screaming Man nevertheless turns on an improbable transformation by the main character, a father in war-torn Chad.
Based on the true story of a Kenyan hero, this is a textbook case of what happens to a good story when it's poorly directed.
Rambling indie tale of a young New York City woman who moves in with her mother and sister after graduating from college.
Instead of the romantic claptrap of other adaptations, this is a road movie, and its star is a girl.
Daguerreotypes, one of Agnès Varda's early yet accomplished feature-length documentaries, presages the themes and visual style she would explore in her subsequent work.

Turkish writer-director Nuri Bilge Ceylan's sixth feature film is about a murder investigation in which the lives of each of the men assigned to the methodical task of meting out justice are also under scrutiny-by their colleagues and by the filmmaker.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Pixar's La Luna and the New York-set A Morning Stroll are the standouts in this program of Oscar-nominated animated shorts.
This deceptively simple, day-in-the-life-of documentary about Iranian director Jafar Panahi is an act of defiance against the filmmaking ban imposed on him by Iranian authorities.
Lebanese director Nadine Labaki's strikingly original second feature presents a clever solution to ending sectarian violence.
Although director Brian Lilla is neither a compelling storyteller nor a journalist, he presents a passionate and cogent scientific argument against Chile's latest dam project in Patagonia Rising.

This film by director Bruce Beresford (Driving Miss Daisy) is a formulaic, multi-generational story about a New York City lawyer on the verge of divorce who goes home to Mama, a pot-smoking denizen of Woodstock.
The first live-action movie by the Persepolis filmmaking team of Marjane Satrapi and Vincent Paronnaud is not as engaging as their animation debut, but is beautifully scored and well-acted.

True Wolf is ostensibly about a Montana couple's life with their adopted wolf, but the documentary's lack of cohesiveness fails to connect us to either the exigencies of that existence, or to the wolf.
A strikingly original depiction of the role of women in a complicated struggle for human rights.

Audiences will not "like the truth" that this newly declassified footage of a Guantanamo detainee reveals, although the title actually refers to the interrogators of 15-year-old Omar Khadr who deny the obvious truth of their prisoner's predicament.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Doctored offers no fix for the problems it identifies, beyond a visit to your local chiropractor.
Based on an E.L. Doctorow short story, Jolene is an apt example of how stories about women who are in abusive relationships can be turned into sexual exploitation.
This portrait of a strident white farmer and his family in Zimbabwe is interesting for its close-up view of life there, but it skips too many details and ends up being morally ambiguous.

Yolande Moreau captures both the purposeful, single-minded woman who does other people's laundry to support her painting, and Séraphine de Senlis, whose secret life of fervid creativity drove her to madness.
If you're an omnivore, Food, Inc. is your "must-see" documentary this year.

Celebrated filmmaker Jia Zhangke melds fiction and non-fiction filmmaking to portray the new betrayals in store for the Chinese as they shift to capitalism--ones not very different from the old betrayals of a paternalistic society.
This documentary about the arcane rituals involved in identifying a child who is a reincarnated lama will leave audiences%u2014except perhaps Buddhists%u2014with far too many unanswered questions.
A lifeless autobiography, a shadow of the director's genius, The Beaches of Agnès is strictly for the film historian.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This entertaining new comedy from Nora Ephron, about famed chef Julia Child and author Julie Powell, is a homage to every woman's unique talent for reinvention.
The director knows how to exploit beautiful scenery, but he fails at the most basic task of a filmmaker, which is to communicate emotion.
A fascinating portrait of the dark side of Japanese society, Ying Li's film is not so much about Japan's shrine to its war dead as it is an indictment of Japan's wartime aggression.
Compelling German drama about a 67-year-old seamstress who is not content to wait out the final part of her life "aging gracefully."

The third in a cinematic trilogy of pre-Christian Inuit life that began with Atanarjuat, The Fast Runner, Before Tomorrow is an outstanding film which presents a distinctly feminine view of the history of the Inuit.
movie_title: Before Tomorrow (Le Jour avant le lendemain) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Another unusual and thoughtful portrait of ritualized violence from one of America's master filmmakers.
An excellent introduction to the rigors of ranching life, this documentary nevertheless exploits Americans' romantic views of the West.
South Korean documentary-narrative hybrid centers on an aging couple and their ox.
The eponymous "girl" is the only reason to see this dull, misconceived drama that centers on a defamed male journalist who takes a job with a rich industrialist.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining debut film about a Harlem laundry worker who dreams of becoming a famous tenor.
In this entertaining mix of documentary and narrative film, Kurdish-Iranian director Bahman Ghobadi turns his camera on the Iranian underground music scene.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One man's rant for privatizing public education, uncomplicated by the thorny issues of curriculum reform or classroom practices

This documentary about the innovative dancer and choreographer Anna Halprin is an excellent introduction to post-modern dance and to an iconic American artist whose work is now little-known outside of dance circles.
Kosashvili's film accomplishes precisely what Chekhov's short story achieves: It draws us into the lives of characters who do nothing momentous or meaningful.
This poetic documentary about the Japanese fascination for smaller worlds and their arthropod inhabitants is also an introduction to all things Japanese.
This drama about a French film producer and his family is entertaining despite a flawed script, and notable for its excellent direction by newcomer Mia Hansen-Løve.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Outstanding second feature about an unusual summer in the life of a five-year-old boy and his father in the indigenous lands of the Mexican Maya. Mexican director Pedro González-Rubio received the New Directors Award at the San Francisco International Fil
A well-researched story about the most recent art-world fleecing, this "documentary" will appeal to those interested in what the cultural elite do to amuse themselves.
Director Julia Loktev finds accomplished simplicity, a rare quality in the early work of any director.
Director Moussa Touré's allegorical underpinning transforms this rather predictable plot, ripped from familiar headlines around the world, into a decidedly Senegalese story.
Paolo and Vittorio Taviani brilliantly merge documentary and fiction in this film about a prison production of Shakespeare's Julius Caesar.
An inspired approach to biography [...] a thoughtful portrait of this gifted artist.
movie_title: Jia Zhangke, a Guy from Fenyang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rather than allowing Hooligan Sparrow to represent [subject Ye Haiyan's] achievement, [director Nanfu] Wang continually highlights her own plight.
This inventive adaptation of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry's children's book is beautifully realized in CG and stop-motion animation techniques.
Skillfully realized story of a dybbuk, a diabolical spirit from Jewish folklore who addresses wrongdoings.
Newtown is the filmmaker's biased narrative of that village as one defiled by an outcast who is never named by her or her subjects.
Intelligent but sometimes discursive documentary about African-American author James Baldwin.
Great performances by Valeria Bruni Tedeschi and Micaela Ramazzotti anchor this commedia al'Italiana-inspired movie.
A necessary, if not always well-constructed, examination of the perilous state of reproductive rights in the United States.
Homage of movie musicals of years past has a certain charm but fails to live up to its illustrious predecessors.
Lina Rodriguez's excellent sophomore feature overturns the longstanding male perspective of female teenage characters as little more than objects of desire.
movie_title: This Time Tomorrow (Mañana a esta hora) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With Black Girl, Ousmane Sembene crafts one of cinema's finest portraits of African neocolonialism.
A young doctor has a crisis of conscience in the latest incisive drama from the Dardenne Brothers.
Curtis' steady hand, apparent in My Week With Marilyn (2011), elevated that mediocre screenplay, as it does this one.
Well-directed documentary about a Palestinian woman who starts a catering business in a refugee camp.
Had it incorporated women's voices, Lough's documentary would be exceptional, but as it stands it is a good primer on the "dark web."
Nancy Buirski's excellent and timely documentary presents the legacy of one courageous black woman.
[A] skillfully plotted debut feature.
The audience [...] is, at best, being subjected to a rather dull story about an equivocal protagonist.
Dakota Fanning is outstanding in the starring role.
This year's slate of live-action Oscar nominated shorts runs the quality gamut.
This year's animated shorts category at the Oscars is marked by two obvious standouts.
All of the Oscar nominees in the documentary short category address pressing social issues in the United States[,] and they do so with great humanity.
A documentary that is at once about a police department, a city and, by extension, a nation on the brink of dissolution.
Rather than the psychological thriller one might expect, The Clan is a senseless and sanguinary depiction of criminal behavior.
The latest and most intensely personal movie by the celebrated Chinese director Jia Zhangke won the top prize at Cannes' Directors Fortnight.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is a timeless story, although not in [director Antonio] Pietrangeli's hands, an archetypal one.
movie_title: I Knew Her Well (Io la conoscevo bene) (1965)

movie_review_blurb: Chilean filmmaker Pablo Larraín's last in a trilogy of films about his country's political landscape, No is the story of the 1988 national referendum which unseated a dictator.
An impressive debut feature, Gimme the Loot is also an unusual take on characters who want to leave their stamp on "the city that never sleeps."
Sparkles just like an old-fashioned musical--it's beautifully designed and skillfully directed.
Herman's House shows off the talents of several young principal crew members, and that of the director who makes his documentary feature debut, but it lacks the gravitas of human-rights filmmaking.

Heinzerling has a great eye, and his conventional, low-key approach to cinematography in Cutie and the Boxer-no shaky camera, very few tracking shots, and adequate lighting-puts all the emphasis on his subjects.
Despite beautiful cinematography and Juliette Binoche in the title role, Bruno Dumont's biopic is a dull fictionalized depiction of three days of the eponymous sculptor's 30-year confinement.
Women's cinematic quests for identity are singular, as they so often involve reminiscences of a dead relative... Elena adds another assured and courageous voice.

Unfortunately, Provost mostly avoids Leduc's substantial literary contribution in favor of depicting her life solely through her friends and mentors, and her mother Berthe with whom she had a dysfunctional relationship.
If Closed Curtain seems at times too self-reflexive, it is Panahi's despair which rescues the movie, exquisite in its rendering, and terrifying for its ability to clutch at the soul.
[Haluk] Bilginer's [performance] alternates between brooding melancholy and sharp-tongued contemptuousness, failing to reach the tragic dimensions which the writers intended.
It is not often that movies so authentically portray the travails of working-class characters in developed countries.
An unremarkable thriller elevated by a few excellent performances and Paolo Virzì's direction.
Excellent performances from the ensemble cast [...] elevate what is an otherwise theatrical treatment of a timeworn narrative.
An excellent cast, a solid script, and a few surprises about the little-known circumstances of life as an Arab-Israeli citizen make A Borrowed Identity an absorbing film.
A profound commentary on the lasting effects of the Nazi era on the German people.
A portrait of the artist as increasingly uncomfortable with his talent and his Hollywood milieu.
An expertly edited mosaic of the political party.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An exercise in self-pity that will test the limits of [Jafar Panahi's] most sympathetic audiences.
[Suffragette] will resonate with audiences because while it is a historical drama, its modernity is felt in the predicament of its working-class hero.
Serves as a good introduction to the work of "the father of African cinema."
A fascinating, fly-on-wall portrait of patriarchal politics and power.
This drama about pedophile priests replaces the depiction of ethical and moral dilemmas with all the details one might hear on a daytime reality show.
Ave Maria is the standout in this year's quintet of Oscar-nominated live-action shorts.
Compilation of filmed interviews with industrial designers who talk about the philosophy of design, rather than the objects they designed.
Sorin's nihilism is a matter of taste, but his claim that this movie bears any resemblance to Wild Strawberries is frankly disingenuous.
Among that rare group of documentaries about child poverty that does not advocate for anything except hope.

Like all of Heddy Honigmann's films, Oblivion, set in her native Lima, Peru, obliterates any previously held notions we might have had about the subjects she confronts, which, in this case, are intentional forgetfulness and the forgotten of Lima.
In an astonishingly accomplished first feature, female filmmaker Xiao Jiang puts an entirely different face on China's Cultural Revolution.
The result is an infomercial rather than a film.
Although Sophie Scholl is noteworthy for its performances, it will undoubtedly fail to capture the popular imagination here.
It's a credit to MacDonald that she provides a little-known view of Harlem's halcyon days, but what's missing is the pith and marrow: We feel that the women still elude us.
We find [Bergman]at 87, sifting through his pictures, wondering at the choices he's made.
An advertorial rather than a solid piece of investigative journalism.
Raymont gets the most out of what little footage and still photographs remain from 1994.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A paean to the resiliency of the human spirit.
An aimless pastiche of archival footage and current interviews of former Vietnam vets court-martialed and jailed for their anti-war activities.
John Moore's The Omen is not as frightening as Richard Donner's 1976 version--Moore resorts to scare tactics rather than impending horror.
An auspicious first feature; although relentlessly benighted, it is nevertheless beautifully filmed and well-acted.
While the performances are flawless, Michael Seitzman's screenplay is embarrassingly sophomoric, so much so that the film's denouement completely obliterates its feminist message.
How people remember, how they fictionalize their memories, and the nature of memory itself are all part of the fascination of After Life.
An absorbing and eye-opening documentary about war poetry.
It is that lack of small-minded judgment which distinguishes The Beauty Academy of Kabul and which makes it thoughtful, yet so much fun to watch.
An insipid script by Laws of Attraction co-writer Aline Brosh McKenna packs a few droll one-liners, but mostly the film only aspires to its chick-lit roots.
Mostly manages to feel authentic and uplifting, putting a human face on a complex colonial culture.
Wheel of Time is flawed because Herzog attempts to illustrate faith through the exercise of faithfulness. He runs after the poetry of Buddhism and it eludes him.
Manderlay is shorter but just as dull, pretentious and condescending as Dogville.
Like many "documentaries" that are essentially homages, Trudell often lacks context.
While Blossoms of Fire avoids the fluff and sensationalism of an Elle article, it is by no means the last word on Zapotec culture.
Its indictment of Iranian mores is no less incisive than that of The Circle.
Will raise many more questions about totalitarianism, and about the foreign policies of Western countries with regard to North Korea, than it ever answers.
U-Carmen is brash, often strident, yet in the end it is not cathartic.
In his retelling of the events, Beauchamp reconstructs the legacy of diaspora.
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although Chabrol is celebrated as a master of suspense, his great movies, like this one and the underappreciated masterpiece Madame Bovary (also starring Huppert), meticulously expose the mechanisms of our entrapment.
ike Bresson's movies, Three Monkeys is an archetype of the cinematic form in which the elements are stripped to their essences so that what remains is immaterial--as insubstantial as cinema can be.
Grosbard...forgets the need for character motivation, point of view, or anything else that might make this compelling subject an interesting film.
movie_title: The Deep End of the Ocean (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Excessively enigmatic, Deserted Station nevertheless provides an allegory for modern-day Iran.
The only thing to be said for The Disappearance of Garcia Lorca is that it features some excellent performances by the most accomplished Latino actors working in film today.
[Frears is] a master at creating a cinematic style that perfectly reflects the subject of the screenplay.
Fincher...meticulously avoids cinematic hyperbole, which is what gives Zodiac such uncommon authenticity.
It was Yu's mistaken belief that experts would detract from her intimate approach that gives the film its tenuity, the lingering sense that far too little has been explored.
movie_title: In the Realms of the Unreal (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Unrelentingly pedantic, it's also utterly humorless.
A wonderful reminder that adult life is never as difficult as puberty was.
Don't expect sex, satire or "upstairs/downstairs" irony, just a good song, a flash of sequins and the possibility of a wartime romance--oh, the joys of nostalgia!
A film that's so recondite, it's barely there.
The director fails to overcome a script that ignores the backstory of the characters, and that agonizingly details minor subplots.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Reeves discovers an allegory for the ebb and flow of life in these uncertain times.
Evocative, beautifully photographed and skillfully directed.
Coleman's ethnographic style resembles the American masters and provides a startling insider's view of the selfless devotion of the monks.
Herzog illustrates through both Dorrington and the Rastafarian the wonder of simply being human.
Possesses a disarming veracity which is not easily dismissed.
The problem with Keeping Mum is that the slaughter is very real and, worse, the victims are often innocent or otherwise undeserving of their fate.
Mostly an exercise in hyperbole...flawed by a lack of perspective
The Francis brothers maintain a lively pace and a satirical mood.
The performances are so good and the images so darkly expressive that Khrzhanovsky's experiment with cinematic deconstructionism nearly works.
Magical and enchanting.
movie_title: When the Sea Rises (Quand la Mer Monte...) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Can be enjoyed as a quick overview of the contemporary American art scene.
movie_title: Who Gets to Call It Art? (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Excellent performances by lead actors Beglau and Martin Wuttke...as well as an unforgettable performance by Nadja Uhl...humanize the unfamiliar internal politics of Germany.
movie_title: Die Stille nach dem Schuß (The Legend of Rita) (The Legends of Rita) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dissertation, not a story.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With the exception of an agonizingly long and overwritten opening scene, Private Fears is an absorbing if somewhat theatrical drama of six intertwined lives.
Li's documentary approach brooks no sentimentality in its portrayal of the loss of innocence.
Everything is in Varda's perspicacious photos.
The actors' Herculean effort to extract meaning from their characters provides a few moments of relief from this troublesome story.
A perverse male fantasy masquerading as an earnest story about a woman's life-altering experience.
Luchetti's craftsmanship is evident in the movie's fluid on-location cinematography, excellent production design, and its wonderful period score.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's social commentary is so subtle, and arises so naturally from the plot, that Tuya's Marriage might be mistaken for simple, straightforward entertainment.
One only wonders whether distributor Magnolia Pictures and Perelman's cast and crew grasp the film's undisguised misogyny.
Far too many disparate themes are never woven together to explain the underlying purpose of the film's journey.
His conflation of reality and narrative filmmaking, unique as it may seem, that doesn't always work.
Signature Herzog: thoughtful, often hilarious, but also overwrought and lengthy.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In each situation, punctuated with animated sequences that reflect the teenager's fantasies, Burstein recalls the bittersweet experience of being 18.
For the sophisticated viewer, it is like looking at Bourgeois' work in the company of a good friend.
movie_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a cliched script and bland direction by writer-director Gina Prince-Bythewood, The Secret Life of Bees celebrates women and girls, and for that reason should not be written off as just another chick flick.

The filmmakers, plying the easier path of sentimentality, never explore the psychological complexity of the disenfranchisement suffered by the Phrasavaths. Instead, they emphasize the everyday humiliations of poverty%u2014the better to place blame.

If you can't define "Brechtian," this documentary, ostensibly about the Public Theater's production of Mother Courage and Her Children, may elude you, yet the all-too-brief glimpses of Meryl Streep finding meaning in the play may make it all worthw
Skillfully written and entertaining documentary that is also a clever investigation into the professional lives of the world's best dancers, the ballerinas of Russia's Kirov Ballet.
Matteo Garrone's provocative film fictionalizes the bleak, horrifying tales of ordinary people swept into the businesses of the Camorra, while illustrating the global reach of the Neapolitan Mafia.
Documentary portrait of five women artists is the wine-party view of art from socialite-filmmaker Chiara Clemente.

An example of how a master filmmaker can make the past--in this case a World War II-era massacre--possess a bracing immediacy. Polish director Andrzej Wajda's film earned an Oscar nomination last year despite its departure from every Hollywood con
Carlos Saura's valentine to fado, Portugal's blues music, is exciting despite the director's imposition of dance production numbers which add a note of dissonance.
This skillfully made documentary by a spurned lover of the wildly successful photographer Cindy Sherman carries the deadening taint of exploitation and self-promotion.

People of faith will see divinity in The Song of Sparrows, and the rest of us the presence of something greater than ourselves, a perfection that can only be understood in observation of another person's life.
Story of a young man's efforts to reconcile his imagined paradise with the harsh landscape he hopes will sustain him offers a romantic vision of nomad life on the steppes of Kazakhstan.
The film is an illustration of Van Sant's virtuosity, as well as a textbook example of cinema's potential to place us squarely in the emotional landscape of another human being.
Driven solely by the filmmaker's prosaic associations. Portabella does not discover the composer through his music.
movie_title: The Silence Before Bach (Die Stille vor Bach) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While it is absorbing to see girls in this environment, the psychological and sociological perspective which the filmmakers bring teaches us about their subjects rather than allowing us to get to know them.
Jia's films are singular and beautiful and, like the opening tracking shot in Still Life, a study in the expressive potential of the medium.

Only in a Chabrol film can subjects like lust, obsession and family dynamics not lead you to a psychological insight. That's why The Bridesmaid is so much fun to watch. It's scary and seductive, and you're not bothered in the least by that connection.
A riveting portrait of disenfranchisement.
Kudos to Schlöndorff for celebrating the woman who sacrificed that glory for the greater good--and who continues to fight.
Clever as the commentary may be, you simply don't care what happens to the protagonist.
This story is right out of America's collective unconscious.
Composed of dramatic and thoughtful readings followed by surprisingly candid interviews.
A Lebanese version of Steel Magnolias--a delightful valentine to women of a particular time and place.
Sokurov has thought deeply about his subject, but he does not dwell in the emotional and spiritual lives of this mother and son.
A film with no discernable point of view that's directed at no definable audience.
Gaggero's vision is gentle and optimistic and, like all things which come upon us slowly and gracefully, it possesses an undeniable verisimilitude.
After 40 minutes of schoolgirl and schoolboy reminiscences, and the filmmaker's attempts to filter history through nostalgia, the documentary is about as appealing as a home movie.
movie_title: The Sugar Curtain (El Telon de azucar) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Captures the fragile and fleeting impression you often have of life, that's actually closer to life itself than the more comforting, linear perspectives of narrative film.
The filmmaker compels us to see in the dark, to recognize beauty in the absence of color and light.
Through a series of vignettes, interviews with Close's friends and family, the filmmaker reveals the soul of the portraitist.
movie_title: Chuck Close: A Portrait in Progress (1997)

movie_review_blurb: It's worse than male fantasy: It's Austen for Idiots.
Death may come with the half moon, but there remains a promise of rebirth%u2014the full moon, which illuminates even the desperate landscape of Kurdistan.
Niles purposefully seeks out quirkiness rather than providing meaningful demonstrations of craft.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the drama, there is nothing in The Water Horse that will frighten young children. The cast is good, and the special effects are even better.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Few will doubt the priest's claims given the Dominican Republic's appalling human-rights record; one only wishes they had been explored in an objective documentary format.
A reflective and thought-provoking documentary, guided by Williams' sensitivity to the subtle and not-so-subtle forms of racism that spurred those events.
Lives up to its promise of definitiveness...a significant piece of journalism.
[A film with] power to stir a memory of beauty beheld and shared.
A highly imaginative film, beautifully scored and well-acted.
Touching tale of an unlikely friendship.
All-ages spotted canine caper updates classic.
Boring vampire blood bath isn't for kids.
The board game is a lot more fun.
A grand, sweeping journey of the heart.
Pleasant comedy for older kids and up.
Stunning footage of aquatic life.
Lively musical adventures for toddlers.
movie_title: Disney's Little Einsteins - Team Up For Adventure (2006)

movie_review_blurb: After Columbine, this dark comedy isn't as funny.
Cute Winnie the Pooh adventure for little ones.
movie_title: Pooh's Grand Adventure: The Search for Christopher Robin (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Choppy L.A. thriller. Absolutely not for kids.
An unexpectedly classy film. Not for kids.
You'd be better off making your own sock puppets.
movie_title: Rockin' with Roseanne - Calling All Kids! (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Three charming stories about loving families.
movie_title: I Love you like Crazy Cakes...and More Stories About Families

movie_review_blurb: So-so spy movie for kids featuring Emma Roberts.
Simple story for kids based on the classic books.
Twin Sister Sisters' magic made for tweens.
Rollicking Halloween fun for tweens and up.

Not everyone will find Trapero's uncompromising storytelling and quiet camerawork to their liking, but once more with Born and Bred he demonstrates a masterful ability to unite the physical and the metaphorical, the social and the sensual.
This is a movie whose power and emotional pitch lie in the understated: the discreet performances, the lack of special effects, the laconic script.
The film's pulse comes in many ways from García's brave and beautiful central performance.

The inclusion of archival footage of Alfonsín and General Galtieri is not only part of Trapero's attention to period detail but also serves to contextualise the film within a wider culture of memory politics.
An accomplished and deeply moving film, gloriously rendered with shifting harmonies, gusto, poise and heartfelt emotion.
If, as the poet Raúl Zurita testifies, the process of returning the dead is about allowing the living to grieve, The Pearl Button is ultimately about cinema's unique way of retelling the past.

Bubblier than a prosecco cocktail, Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping is a fake cinematic documentary that (mostly) pulls off a tough feat: it lampoons music genres that are insanely over-the-top.

It's scary and funny but by the time all is said and done, It falls short of being a classic.

If you're looking for a tried-and-true telling filled with elaborate settings and beautiful ball gowns, this glass slipper is the right fit. However, if you're looking for a fresh, modern take on your average fairy tale, don't bother trying on this one.

The Peanuts Movie has all of the elements a true fan would want - the original characters, a nod to past TV specials, even a jazzed-up "wahwah" - but like its stalwart hero, it falls just short of completing the task at hand.
For a film without words, the story speaks volumes.
Parts of the story are quite dark and unnecessarily gruesome for younger audiences. Even a bedtime story is turned into a humorless plot point.

Directors Pete Docter ( Monsters, Inc .; Up) and Ronnie del Carmen ( Dug's Special Mission) have created a masterful study of family dynamics. Like the Oscar-winning Up, Inside Out takes great care in weaving complex ideas into a children's tale.

Tim Johnson ( Antz) has capitalized on DreamWorks' proprietary animation platform, Apollo to create a rich, intricate setting...But the technology doesn't save the film from falling flat on other levels.

Paddington...comes off as a charming character. The kind of character that children around the world have fallen in love with...But even with all the bear's charm, a plodding pace and a questionable plotline leave the film version less desirable to watch.

The Book of Life's meticulous, eye-popping visuals alone would be reason enough to upgrade to a 3-D seat. But once you hear the inspired renditions of Radiohead's Creep and Biz Markie's Just a Friend...you will be hooked on this tongue-in-cheek tale.

Phenom Quvenzhané Wallis proves her Oscar nomination for Beasts of the Southern Wild was no fluke. As a modern-day Annie, Wallis shines with her sweet portrayal. However, her performance alone can't save the film from being a dim adaptation.
Disney has another hit in its repertoire with this heartfelt story of sisterly love and one of the few films released in 3-D this year that splendidly incorporates the technology into the plot line.

However, even with all of well-intentioned references and good humor, Penguins doesn't break new ground. The film is fun, light-hearted fare that could be watched in the comfort of a long car ride to Grandma's house.
While the laughs are predictable, this is sweet family fare.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fun, fantastical tale for the toddler set but may not translate to older children who are too tied up with heady video games. For adults, it may take you back to a time when crayons were king.
Even the trait that should endear the audience to Norm, his infamous " Arctic Shake," in which the bear goes into uncontrollable fits of dancing and twerking, becomes unbearable to watch.
The Lego Movie has enough wit and wisdom to send a recession-age message to families on the importance of thinking through problems with creativity.

The main reason families enjoy the series is Po, thanks to Jack Black's frenetic and friendly approach. There's just enough huggable and HiYa! moments to keep the animated film's core audience chomping on their popcorn and glued to the screen.

Big Hero 6 offers something for everyone: action, camaraderie, superheroes and villains. But mostly, Baymax offers a compassionate and healing voice for those suffering, and a hug that can be felt through the screen.
The film adaptation tells the true-life tale of the Beams with such intensity and urgency that a box of tissues may not be enough to keep up with the water works.
The true standout is the achingly riveting Rosamund Pike. As Rosalie Quaid, Pike becomes a force greater than the script at hand.
But what really stands out are the themes of friendship, problem solving and learning to be true to yourself. Ferdinand does not back down to his bullies and stands firm in his beliefs.

The storytelling is uneven and may be difficult to understand for the younger demographic. However, that target audience will still connect to the frenetic battle scenes, sophomoric humor (butt jokes, anyone?) and engaging characters.

On the surface, Zootopia is a witty, wondrous buddy-cop film... At a deeper level, the film allows parents to bring tough topics to the dining-room table, topics such as bullying, stereotyping and inclusiveness.
In the end, the only statement being made is that this is an adequate family film. Oh, and love conquers all.

The attention to detail in this film is exquisite, from the gold flakes on Belle's ballroom gown to the Fantasia-like theatrics of the Be Our Guest feast. All of the acting heavy hitters truly bring those inanimate objects to life.
The movie doesn't come close to the humor and heart of [Illumination's] summer hit, The Secret Life of Pets.
The film also inventively incorporates CG animation, live-action sock puppets and a flipbook to bring to life the pages of Pilkey's sentimental ode to boyhood.

movie_review_blurb: It's hard not to smile when watching Trolls, a sweet and humorous take on the pursuit of happiness.

If you're willing to dive deep into the dark side of parenthood, this is the film for you.

With all of the comedic stars, the film has a fair share of LOL moments. And while you won't find any revelatory insight into the mind of your pet, parents and children alike will fall for this fun, fast-paced furry tale.

Another huge improvement from its predecessor is the animation, from the way the kelp sways in the ocean to Hank's camouflaging metamorphosis. The filmmakers provide a dynamic, colorful backdrop worthy of 3-D viewing.

Director James Bobin duplicates the visually stunning world he inherited from Tim Burton, who helmed 2010's Alice in Wonderland. However, the meandering pacing and convoluted storytelling make for a lackluster tea party.

It's one of the few films in which the 3D enhancement is justified. Each scene captures the essence of each animal so vividly that children in the audience were reaching out to the screen to try to "touch" the fur.

Moana pays homage to Pacific Islanders by introducing us to a strong female character unlike any we've seen in mainstream films - a hero who is both smart and sympathetic, strong and compassionate, independent yet belongs to a group.

All in all, Moore does make a point. That a peaceful approach to life is better than forceful, and perhaps there is so much available in the U.S. that we are becoming an apathetic nation instead of a world power.

As far as acting, the cast does well.
You hardly recognize Cooper, with a muscular physique, beard and kind of a swagger.
The acting is what makes this film.

The film depends on the main star's performance to carry the story along, and Tom Hiddleston does just that.

The camera follows models and Simons and we do get an inside look into what makes a fashion house stay on top.
What may be surprising- -- or not -- is the camaraderie between Ryan Gosling and Russell Crowe. Their comedy is akin to Two Stooges.
Vince has the killer smile, Turtle drives and looks at girls, E is quieter and Drama is all over the place. Just going along for the ride through Tinseltown and enjoying every minute.
Not all of your favorite scenes may be here, but the ones that are, will satisfy.
The Force is still here.

With shamefully obvious nods to the father/son sentimentality of traditional Disney 'toons and even an awkward love interest, Barnyard is a mishmash of modern cartoon clichés.

Even if your children like dinosaurs, don't let them be exposed to the offensive, insensitive, intolerably anti-humanist and racist propagandizing that is draped around them in this film. No plot, no heart, no soul.
