This delicate, charming low-budget Irish film is a gem worth discovering. A thoughtful and whimsical film.
As a film it is uneven but as a news document it is uncompromising and compelling.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ignore the underlying fact that The Proposal is one big cliché of a movie and relish Bullock's ability to handle slapstick comedy as well as the smart line delivery.
Stunning big-screen cowboy film.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: A lumbering and largely unamusing comedy adventure. Ferrell and McBride are occasionally funny when they head into improv territory, but on the whole it is a limp affair.
The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3 is a classy updating of the original, strong on pace and atmosphere, with Travolta and Washington making a great doubleact.
There are perhaps just too many characters to take on board, but when it works well it's spectacular.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film may lack great depth, but it is a visual treat about films within films and packed with top performances.
Life, death and comedy... Funny People is a thoughtful and funny comedy indulgence.
An amazingly powerful movie that will leave you reeling. This mustsee movie is dazzlingly well made.
District 9 is one of the very best films of the year - packed with suspense, action, humour and great performances, and directed with real style and panache... brilliant!
A modern romance for grown-ups... a sweet-natured, funny, deeply-romantic tale that brims with energy and is blessed with top-notch performances.
Looks terrific when up in the air amidst the dogfights, but falls flat back on the ground.
It is an engrossing and thoughtful film that balances bullets and blood with moments of introspection and musings about the nature of family.
Daft but fun.
An astonishingly impressive and entertaining disaster movie... one of the must-see films of the year.
A smart satirical comedy.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Truly one of the greatest films ever.
An Education is a brilliant learning curve - one of the best British films of the year.
Kick-Ass is a gloriously bloodthirsty action romp that is funny, violent and stunningly entertaining.
A cumbersome and trite "dangerous rise of technology" story that fails to engage.
This scattershot comedy hits a few targets but is so desperate to amuse it feels more like a series of rejected TV sketches than a movie.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, Fantastic Mr Fox is clever. But it is also a rather slight film that you smile at rather than really enjoy.
The best zom-com since Shaun of the Dead... a delightfully sharp and smart comedy actioner that is funny, thrilling and just a little bit gory.
It is a fun-packed romp, beautifully animated and lacking any heavy-handed 'messages', instead focusing on the joy and innocent delight of Christmas and the pleasures in old-fashioned family values.
The Soloist is a moving and well-made film, but you just can't help feeling it is a little too contrived and simplistic.
A well-made piece of period drama that sorely lacks any lightness or passion.
This stylish tale of teen terror is impressive but unsatisfying.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Twilight films manage to cleverly blend melodrama with supernatural thrills, and while the film is not without its silly moments and cringeworthy dialogue it does deliver the drama and emotional highs we have come to expect.
Think a Welsh blend of Glee and School of Rock, with a great soundtrack and young cast led by the terrific Aneurin Barnard as talented but troubled student Davey.

This latest film featuring the sleuthing duo of Sherlock Holmes and Dr Watson, as re-imagined by Guy Ritchie, is strong on romping high adventure and action and modest in terms of actual by-the-numbers detective work.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The effects, action and set are all terrific, with Colin Farrell on great form as the determined spy up against his lethal wife.
A deliriously sleazy black comedy thriller that is resolutely adult in tone and content but overflows with wonderful performances, fast-paced thrills and memorable dialogue.

Against all of the odds this 3D reboot is an engagingly action-packed and freewheeling affair, blessed with perfect chemistry between Brit Andrew Garfield and Hollywood star Emma Stone and some grandstanding special effects moments.
An uplifting and sweetly inspirational documentary.
An engaging blend of martial arts and film noir.
movie_title: The Girl from the Naked Eye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [The] film can never quite find the balance between fairy tale and Joan of Arc-style fable and gets bogged down in questing when it should be delivering magic and adventure.
It is a strikingly well made film that pulls no creative punches.
Should thrill, challenge and provoke audiences ready for [Scott's] signature brand of intelligent and visceral film-making.
In the end there is enough pregnancy humour to give audiences a good old belly laugh.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Sightseers is a blissful bit of dark, funny and at times very bloody entertainment.
Me And Me Dad is an intimate family film par excellence.
Offers an intriguing glimpse into attitudes of old France as they talk about their experiences over the past 60 years.
A deliciously stylish hard-boiled crime drama, Andrew Dominik's violent and bleakly funny film is a grimly nihilistic film that revels in its harsh and brutal urban landscape.
A bright and breezy jaunt through Europe that delivers enough laughs, action and thrillingly staged adventure to keep the young ones happy.
The space battle scenes are impressive, Julia Dietze is sexy and demure as the Nazi schoolteacher sent to Earth and there are genuinely funny moments.

While initially a little heavy-handed as it sets up its character-heavy format its strength comes as its young, inexperienced, cast make their impact on the film, with the closing scenes powerful and subtly moving.
A spectacularly cool time-twisting sci-fi thriller.
Brimming with leather jackets, submachine guns, fast cars and a suitably grim and brutal determination to catch London's bad guys.

An energetic, amusing and resolutely feel-good-film-with-a-message, 1960s music movie The Sapphires ticks all of the right boxes to click with audiences as well as being a smart advert for Aussie girl power.
Hofman treats Beto and his strange and disturbing condition with gentle respect. What he is going through is horrific, but the film never exploits his increasingly unpleasant physical condition.
The beautifully intense Kelly + Victor is driven with such passion and commitment that it cries out for attention.
It is a familiar story, but one handled with subtly and compassion.
Quite brilliant special effects and emotionally spot-on performances make what sounds like a downbeat film on paper, stirring, uplifting and deeply moving.
It delivers some refreshingly dark down-to-earth crime action.
Seven Psychopaths is a deliriously twisted tale that provides the perfect platform for Walken's deadpan delivery and Rockwell's gleeful loopiness.
A visually stunning dance and performance treat.
A deliriously dark and gloriously bloody crime comedy, Sightseers is a wonderfully eccentric film that delivers twisted humour at some British landmarks.
Ari Graynor and Lauren Anne Miller are great as the sassy pair and despite a veneer of sex, in truth the film is more about friendship.
Elegantly performed and beautifully shot.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Levinson succeeds with his mission to both entertain and inform.
Impressively staged, well performed and rich in melodrama.
Brad Pitt is terrific in this super-stylish crime drama that relishes its brutal mob storyline, inner-city locations and oddball characters.
For the target audience -- probably between 3 and 5 -- it is bang on target.
Meryl Streep delivers a nomination-friendly -- and physically pretty much spot-on -- performance as former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in the oddly superficial The Iron Lady.
Kenneally smartly takes a straightforward and informative spin on the technology and punctuates his interviews with a fine selection of film extracts.
Quirkily perfect in a low-key way.
Incredibly well made and heroically performed. It also really delivers when it comes to creating a strange alien world.
A charming cad romances women useful to his social ambitions in 19th Century Paris.
It deserves to be appreciated for what it is - a smart and quirky tale that is also oddly upbeat.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Great clips and interviews with, among others including Jack Nicholson, Robert De Niro and William Shatner.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Thoughtfully chilling and impressively performed, Deviation is a well-sustained thriller.
The clumsy script never really delivers epic drama. Great action scenes, though.
For all the movie's cute kids and sentimentality, [Damon] is the warm-hearted and convincing heart of this uplifting flick.
Woody Harrelson is at his intense best.
It is loud and entertaining enough to watch, even if it does all feel rather familiar.
Bel Ami has the feeling of a film that can't quite decide on its structure and central story.
Screen veterans Robert Duvall and John Hurt make a strong impact, but sadly Jayne Mansfield's Car is never quite as intriguing as the title suggests.
This Victorian period horror tale is refreshing in that it makes no bones about what it is about - delivering gothic horror thrills pure and simple.
The Imposter is beautifully shot and meticulously researched.
A brutally beautiful survival-horror tale.
Dench and Nighy are sublime as always.
It is a savagely funny and brutally stylish pulp thriller that will impress fans of the genre.
Overlong, but against the odds the usually wooden Channing Tatum is the comedy standout.
Exorcism horror gets the clichéd shaky-camera treatment in this chiller...
It is a film with no great pretensions... just one happy to hit the ground running and focus on violent action.
A wise and witty film about sex - well, actually the lack of it - that's honest and often laugh-out-loud funny.
A deliciously dark horror-thriller that brims with twists, turns and sneaky secrets and manages to spin the horror genre on its head to really deliver some smart chills.
The old-fashioned 2D animation is a welcome change from the current 3D obsession. Charming.
A subtle film that balances drama with gunplay.
It's clever, funny and never smug as Dunham pokes fun at herself and the pseuds around her.
Gritty, slick and maybe a bit too serious, Contraband may be predictable, but it is solid action entertainment.
An eye-popping and vibrant coming together of super-sexy salsa and spectacular, stylish street dance makes for a fun and entertaining bit of 3D cinema.
Starts well but the whole things gets increasingly preposterous.
It's a bit on the dour side but Rapace is always watchable.
Compulsive.
A subtitled film full of mystery and dark tension.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A bit too heavyhanded as hoodies hit the football pitches.
A slick action drama with a strong cast, including Tuppence Middleton, Charlotte Rampling and Michelle Ryan, that delivers in terms of violence, gunplay and conspiracy thrills.
Beautiful animation from Aardman and brimming with swashbuckling gags and delicious moments.
For the majority of its short running time Brüno is a masterpiece of comedy by embarrassment.
The great thing about Drag Me To Hell is that it is laugh-out-loud funny as well as scream-out-loud scary... and as one who has a hard time with horror movies, I must say it is darn entertaining.
Public Enemies is one of those films that lurches between sheer brilliance and muddled moments... but it does feature Johnny Depp in terrific form and is worth seeing just for him alone.
Fantasy fable impresses and indulges in equal measure.
A witty and delicately handled faltering romance. Delightful.
Marvellous musical entertainment packed with performances to relish and enjoy. Wonderful stuff.
A sensationally stylish and tense drama. Great performances all round make this a movie to remember.
Sadly fails to sustain its original interest.
Polished spy drama is a classy affair.
Modestly intriguing, but made with a real sense of commitment.
As a comedy it can never sustain itself, and while there are moments to enjoy, it is all pretty forgettable, which is a shame because the concept remains an amusing one.
Keeps you guessing and wondering right up until the end.
This is moving stuff, thoughtfully handled and well performed.
Fonda is smart casting as Mephistopheles, while sultry Mendes is topnotch eye-candy.
The characters never convince and it spirals into plain silliness.
The supporting cast are all terrific, as are the Irish locations.
Stylishly and thoughtfully directed by Nick Cassavetes, Alpha Dog is occasionally chilling, but always absorbing.
Gambling drama never seems to draw the right cards. Best to fold...
Chillingly enjoyable.
A deliciously dark affair, brimming with impressively gritty performances but still managing to balance magical wonder with breathless excitement.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Having an angry Samuel L Jackson as your nasty neighbour would be anybody's idea of bad news. Tense and terrifying, this is a smart thriller.
It is a full-throttle action film which works best if you leave your brain at the door... and there's nothing wrong with that!
This bit of festive froth is nothing original but it delivers enough moments to make you smile.
Riveting but uncomfortable. No masterpiece.
A brilliant, breathless action romp. Daniel Craig is electrifying.
A strange but cool comedy.
Strong on stars but short on real drama. Impressive but ultimately unmemorable.
Set this alongside gun-wielding military bad guys and the expected conspiracy plots and the film looks set to fit easily alongside the other Indy films.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Forget Wedding Crashers... this is a plain old Wedding Disaster.
A SMOOTH tale of murder and deception... great cast and fine film.
Enjoyably tall tale with Gere terrific as the outrageous hoaxer.
A FUN comedy of epic Biblical proportions with Carell in fine form.
Fantasy flick fails to engage.
It's peppered with thrilling computer-generated action, but there's still something endearingly old-fashioned about McClane and his bare-knuckled way of dealing with bad guys.
Wipeout! Surf's Up is terrific entertainment for all the family.
Zwick does a fine job in combining a broad range of elements and turning them into a compulsive and thought-provoking adventure and is aided by beautiful cinematography.
Stylish, sexy and violent World War Two espionage adventure.
Well structured, but rather cold.
Beautifully written and directed and packed with excellent performances.
This formulaic chiller will do little to boost Stallone's career.
Jones ... does offer a brutal form of charisma.
Offers much to enjoy ... and a lot to mull over in terms of love, loyalty and the nature of staying friends.
Makes for fine mindless entertainment, and it does have the selling point of Samuel L. Jackson in a kilt.
The Cat's Meow marks a return to form for director Peter Bogdanovich ...

Thanks to an excellent script from Frank Cottrell Boyce, brilliant cinematography by the legendary Robby Muller and intelligent direction by Winterbottom, the film is constantly amusing and fascinating.
An enjoyable, funny, well-performed comedy with an appealingly old-fashioned feel.
There are moments of real pleasure to be found in Sara Sugarman's whimsical comedy Very Annie-Mary but not enough to sustain the film.
Comes engagingly close to being the assured romantic epic you would want it to be.
A film full of wit, warmth and honest, knowing humor, topped off with a plethora of excellent performances.
A wonderfully stylish thriller packed with astoundingly good performances.
The central performances are ones to cherish.
As a vehicle for the talented Leandra Leal - who plays a pregnant young woman who is seduced and manipulated by an evangelical preacher - it is an impressive affair.
A refreshingly engaging British movie that isn't afraid to go all out for laughs and thrills, leaving its social conscience behind.

This crackingly entertaining sequel is great fun, blending beautiful animation with genuinely funny jokes. In truth it tries to pack in a sub-plot too far, but what the heck - this is great entertainment.
A raw comedy that is intermittently hilarious as it attacks pretty much every taboo around.
What a great shame that such a talented director as Chen Kaige has chosen to make his English-language debut with a film so poorly plotted and scripted.
Nicely tense and intriguing, packed with fine performances.

If you are expecting anything new or profound to be added to the Rocky recipe then guess again - there is nothing fresh or original here, simply a wellconstructed and engagingly-performed film that will tick all the right boxes for Rocky fans.
Blanchett brings her expected professionalism and ability to the role. Her Irish accent is perfect, and she has the charisma and presence to easily hold center stage.
Enjoyable lightweight entertainment and marks stand-up comedian Dylan Moran as an endearing talent to watch.
A classy adaptation of the much-loved Dodie Smith classic.
There are few real belly laughs in Johnny English, but there is enough humor to keep an audience smiling for almost 90 minutes.
A charming, often hilarious experience, brimming with excellent performances and clever dialogue.
Somehow it can't make the leap from an enjoyable light film to a movie to remember.
A gloriously over-the-top revenge comedy-drama that could attract a cult following.
O'Sullivan directs with a great deal of style and elicits fine performances from his cast.
A very well-made genre film with great performances and wonderfully staged sequences.
Despite an interesting premise, Before just can't deliver the dramatic goods.
movie_title: Before You Go (The Memory of Water) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The film rarely musters any great sense of passion or excitement.
There is a welcome lack of pretension about the film, which very simply sets out to entertain and ends up delivering in good measure.
Makes for compulsive and thoughtful viewing.
Idyllic tale despite the back story of racial tension and family abuse. Fanning holds her own in a great cast with Okonedo and Paul Bettany as an unbalanced father in fine form.
Crackingly entertaining documentary.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This modest Scottish caper film is based on real events but it is all a bit too limp to really engage, despite impressive performances from Cox and Mara.

Charlie Kaufman's playfully indulgent brainteaser is intriguing and annoying in equal measure. The cast are great and take it very seriously but while it is a strangely clever film at times, it is never an easy journey..
When Angels & Demons goes into action overdrive it is fun. The locations are terrific, Hanks impressive, the clues absorbing and it is all beautifully shot.
There's the expected amount of fist-play and bloodletting, this is also a nicelymade movie that ably confirms suitably muscular Channing Tatum as a young talent to keep an eye on.
It may be a little too complex and mildly disturbing for wee ones, but its lush gothic style and amazing effects will impress film fans.

This toe-tappingly energetic documentary is a real delight as it traces the talent and traumas of Euro kids as they strive for musical success. It is affectionate, amusing and thoroughly charming - the kids are genuinely thoughtful and engaging.
Beautifully directed by Stephen Frears, Cheri is funny, stylish - and made with class.
An engagingly lightweight romcom.
Star Trek pulsates with adventure and thrills, infectious with its boyish enthusiasm to entertain and respectful enough to pay tribute to the cult series that came before it. See it.
Low budget Brit drama is intriguing but slow.
Slushy but with a great cast...
Admittedly I'm not the target audience, but this heavy-handed tale of cute 'n' spunky young Miley getting back to her rural roots is tough to swallow.
It might lack the political depth of All The President's Men, but this is a cracking tale for a new era... as conspiracy tales go, it is pretty darn impressive.
This dark and bleak comedy is an oddball affair, with Seth Rogen brilliant as a bipolar guard.
This engaging comedy feels like a stretched-out TV pilot, but is nicely put together, with enough laughs to make a refreshing change from usual Brit film fare..
movie_title: Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is a fist-in-your-face scary and, in the end, absorbing film.
Stylish drama fails to set the pulses racing.
A fistful of family fun... brimming with amusing lines, great effects and a series of smart cameo performances.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Heavy-handed French drama is a clumsy affair.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Telstar is still an oddly compulsive story of an exuberant mess of a man who played a key role in British pop history.
Gigantic tries so hard to be cute and quirky it forgets it should also try to be interesting.
In terms of explosions, firepower and sheer shrill, all-action, popcorn entertainment it is hard to see how this big'n'bold sequel can be topped this year.
A nicely gory comedy-horror flick that is a diverting bit of lads' entertainment.
A devilishly smart comedy gem that manages to blend the raunchy and the rowdy with some deliciously left-field humour.
A thoroughly nasty rape revenge tale that's short on logic but strong on blood and brutality. An unpleasant movie experience.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Night at the Museum 2 is a fistful of family fun... brimming with amusing lines, great effects and a series of smart cameo performances.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The thoroughly charming, amusing and insightful Looking For Eric is a complete pleasure... a Ken Loach film brimming with wit and wisdom, interspersed with classic archive moments of Cantona magic.
This is a much more straightforward, all-gunsblazing sci-fi tale of downat-heel humanity at war with some rather nasty machines.
The elements are all there but never fully click into place - more like a TV movie than a big-screen drama.
This toe-curling dip into the sickly-sweet musical world of the Jonas brothers is innocuous and dull.
While the plot is completely daft the film is also engagingly diverting.
The film tries to blend Seventies music, fashion and a grim backdrop, but at heart it's a nasty and limp story told better by other movies.
Cool, sexy, amusing and nicely chilling, Tormented is a smart bit of home-grown slasher mayhem.
This good-natured London-set rom-com for the over-40s is delightfully performed and gently amusing, but it can't shake its need for schmaltz and sentimentality.
The laughs are balanced with some outstanding action sequences.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Globetrotting conspiracy thriller which moves at a fair old pace, blending action with a complex storyline.
Locations are beautiful, but it is all rather straightforward and plodding.

This stylishly-shot psycho-thriller from Sean Ellis is a creditable stab at the horror genre, but it lacks pace and plot. There's not enough blood 'n' gore for horror fans, while thriller admirers may find it too slow.
It is a fresh and engaging film that thankfully lacks the schmaltz and sentimentality of most romcoms aimed at older age-groups.
You come out knowing you have seen some great performances, brilliant direction and beautiful cinematography, but it is just not a film you love.
It is no classic but it is stylish, absorbing and wonderfully put together.
In truth, this good-natured Disney comedy is an engaging romp.
It is a complex movie, but also an absorbing and moving one - and in truth Will Smith does bring an extra dose of class that helps it succeed.
JCVD is an oddball delight as the Muscles from Brussels pokes fun at his he-man persona. The film is amusing, engaging and delightfully strange, with Van Damme in impressive form.
The Wrestler is well worth catching. Against all of the odds you end up caring deeply for this battered and lonely man... plus Mickey Rourke is astonishingly good.
Soderbergh keeps the story straightforward and subdued, rather than layering in the action and the drama. At times it even gets a bit dull.
Yes Man is a terrific feelgood comedy, with Jim Carrey in brilliant form.
This sweet-natured family comedy makes for great entertainment, balancing adventure thrills with a hefty dose of laughter.
Some of it doesn't work, but it remains a gloriously ambitious romantic epic and a truly memorable big-screen movie experience.

It is not all top-notch stuff though. Some of the special effects are plain ropey but luckily the teen romance carries the movie. Naturally room is left at the end for the impending sequel. Something we're sure to get our teeth into...
It is all nicely animated, and has a great voice cast, but is not really special or magical enough to really crack the ultra-competitive kiddie animation market.
The Reader is a thoughtful and absorbing film, which is packed with delicately-structured twists and punctuated with truly impressive performances.
Absorbing.

This cracking cartoon romp is just what you yearn for from an animated movie - smart, funny and not too long! Bolt is brilliantly animated entertainment that will keep both kids and their parents amused.
Woody Allen is back in top form with this sparkling comedydrama. Its highlight is a fabulously funny and passionate performance by Cruz.
The film does a fine job in recreating England of the 60s and 70s - big cars and rubbish clothes - but is less convincing when actors are called upon to play footballers.
Stylishly directed by Alex Proyas (who made I, Robot) this is quite simply over-the-top bonkers.
This charming costume drama might lack the bodice-ripping rowdiness of other recent historical romances, but it is classy and clever.
Nothing much happens in it, but it is still gently absorbing and oddly memorable.
Watchmen is a spectacular visual treat, with special effects to match the ambition of the story. It is way too long... but there is no denying it is a seriously cool and bloody superhero epic.
A violent, refreshingly odd mystery.
This is a compelling and wondrous film. Yes it is a little slow at times, but this is an epic tale of a miraculous romance - and you can't rush such things.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A ham-fisted horror movie that manages to put together deadly demonic possession, Nazi concentration camps and nasty wartime genetic experiments.
This bold and complex British fantasy-drama is an impressive debut for writerdirector Gerald McMorrow.

As an action thriller The International might well lack the full-on fight scenes of a Bourne movie, but it is a smart and sophisticated globetrotting thriller with just the right villain for these troubled times.
Stylishly silly but oddly cool all the same.
Comedy crime caper is more miss than hit.
A swaggering delve into the life of the biggest of all rappers.

It is a nice blend of slapstick fun, a little family pathos and a whole bunch of dogs of all shapes and sizes and is likely to be a popular draw for harassed parents looking for a little respite from the youngsters.
There is the expected smattering of slapstick moments and Connick Jr delivers the requisite outdoorman charm to show Renee just how cool the cold can be.
Eric Walter's fascinating documentary offers a new perspective on the much-told story.
A bold and nicely sustained debut.
Where Frankenstein's Army really shines is with the stunning designs and monster make-up, with the film delivering old-style lumbering monsters without resorting to CGI.

A powerful and illuminating delve into the darker side of young well-to-do British men who dub themselves upper class and celebrate their life of privilege through the excesses of an exclusive Oxford University undergraduate dining society.
Despite being beautifully shot it is often familiar fare that ticks lots of cliché boxes.
A drama that takes pains to sidestep some message-movie conventions but nonetheless fails to deliver an appreciably memorable or thought-provoking experience.
Yes it lacks real dramatic edge and may be seen as a typical British period costume film, but it is also a classily made pleasure that will delight its target audience.

A tough and rather merciless film that makes no bones about the horrors of war. It is also a strong and strident story of how three very different women unite as they defend their home and each other.
Fresh, accessible, delightfully performed and downright hilarious.
A delightfully droll tale of bloody revenge.
A rather watchable film that is reminiscent of The Bodyguard (sans the stalker sub-plot) that also works well as warm-hearted romance with soap opera elements.

Scott Frank's impressively dour and dangerous crime-thriller is the perfect vehicle for Liam Neeson to play a tough and troubled investigator who find himself caught up in a deadly and disturbing case that is like nothing he has ever tackled before.
A well-meaning and occasionally joyous film that is ultimately too scattershot in its format and tone to really work.
A well worked and occasionally well-sustained satire of the wonderfully sleazy Italian murder-mystery melodramas from the 1960s to the '80s ...
A stylishly made genre film that revels in its old-fashioned sense of mystery and suspense.
There are certainly a lot of good things going on in For Those In Peril, but in the end its ambition out-weighs its artistic impact.
Delivers only a few genuine scary moments as it attempts to press some expected spooky buttons.
Delivers a goodly amount of good natured action fun but in the end suffers from being just too low-key for its own good.
It's Lord Of The Flies meets Lost, but in a good way.
The film is rather watchable, defined by impressive performances, striking production design and lustrous cinematography.

Though a contemporary story, it plays out like an old-fashioned dramatic-thriller, and while lacking standout action sequences it sustains itself thanks to atmosphere and performances rather than special effects and grandstanding sequences.
Beautifully shot and engagingly noisy.
Has charm, fun and a glossy sense of adventure to spare.
A quite delightful piece of magical animation.
A darkly amusing Australian comedy that deftly dwells on some of the more unpleasant physical side effects of being a drug smuggler.
No guns-blazing thriller, this is an old-fashioned code-cracking drama.
The central performances are impressive, with Kate Beckinsale especially good ...
While there are pockets of innocent humour and childish antics it lacks a much-needed sense of fun.
A strange and oddly immersive film that makes it audience really work but in the end delivers something rare and original.
In the end you can only applaud its sheer sense of scale, drama, excitement and willingness to take that extra step.
Stylish and beautifully shot.
In the end it all feels rather heavy-handed and over-laden with music cues to the extent that the story rarely gets a chance to breathe and properly develop.

An engagingly freewheeling romp through the grittier side of Brazil, focusing on political corruption and police brutality as it weaves its story of a handful of slum kids who come across information that could bring down a corrupt official.
While this special-effects laden action fest may not tick any highbrow cultural boxes it is a deliciously daft bit of entertainment - frenetic and full of fun.
While this Part 1 is light on old-fashioned adventure it does offer up a tough - and at times moving - transition for its lead character.
Fuqua shoots with style and precision, though some of the fight scenes are a little blurred, but in the end the Washington factor wins through.

It benefits from Arterton's genuine sex appeal, which is delightfully balanced by Fabrice Luchini as her neighbour obsessed with the novel and who sees worrying links between her and the fictional heroine.
Seeing Downey Jr. and Duvall perform together is the film's great pleasure, and while neither tries to outdo each other certainly their roles bring out the best in them.
At its heart, Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes is a classy, exciting genre film that packs in drama, twists and spectacular action.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is a snapshot of a very small period and should be appreciated for its style, rigour and occasional astonishing moments of poetical majesty.
An uneasy rose-tinted blending of striking documentary footage and plodding soap-opera style re-enactment ...

Castles In The Sky may well be modest in scale (and likely to have a greater life on television rather than the big-screen) but it's an entertaining look at a delightfully eccentric and brilliant scientist.
In the end it flatters to deceive and never really delivers in terms of drama or radical thinking.
It delivers a compulsive story, great performances and irresistible songs.
A stylishly made - if rather familiar - action-adventure that will keep fans of swords-and-sandals films more than happy.
Taut, clinical and dryly clever.
Sometimes the good-natured self-referencing gets in the way, but at its heart the film is a real pleasure, brimming with visual gags, clever word play and breezily silly action scenes ...
It may well be something of a one-joke film, but is a great joke and one that gets nicely stretched out, though in admittedly familiar fashion.
A thoroughly entertaining fantasy romp.
A nicely assembled sci-fi film that is breezily exciting if never intellectually challenging.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A rather static and uninvolving film that ticks all of the right boxes but never really engages emotionally.
The return of Wolverine and many other original X-Men gives a welcome jolt of familiarity to this complex, funny and often spectacular adventure.
The transition from comedy to gently revelatory drama is nicely handled in James Rouse's engaging low-budget film.
Get Santa is a thoroughly enjoyable romp, blessed with a spot-on performance by Jim Broadbent, who is quite irresistible in the role of Santa Claus, a part that seems tailor-made for him.
It may well lack the full-blown A-list casting that defines other Marvel films, but the performances here are all pretty much spot on with the film bristling with energy and entertainment.
The discussions -- and lingering sexual tensions -- are all rather familiar, but then About Alex isn't trying to reinvent the wheel, instead it simply makes the most of Zwick's gently witty script.
While Rowan Joffé attempts to rack up the trills and lay down plenty of false trails, this psychological thriller fails to spark despite the good intentions of a game cast.
Engaging but languid and only intermittingly amusing and provocative.
It is to David Gordon Green's credit that he manages to keep Manglehorn intriguing, even if the film never completely delivers.
It all feels rather simple and lacking in the real cleverness audiences come to expect from such fare.
While there is tragedy at its centre, it's also about the power of love - among family, friends and lovers.
A technical tour de force, a beautifully performed and smartly scripted black comedy that will leave its audience keen to head back for more ...
While there is perhaps too much repetition and exposition it is a film that resolutely delivers exactly what its hard-core fan-base is after.
Patema Inverted manages to be both exciting and charming and while it may lack a certain 'wow' factor it is an assured and enjoyable piece of storytelling and looks great on the big screen.

While Septic Man might sound on paper like a little gem that Troma might have made, it is rather slow moving fare with much rambling around in dark sewers calling out for aid rather than traditional horror fare.
A wonderfully strange and deliriously funny low-budget offering.
movie_title: I Am A Knife With Legs (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It manages to deliver just what fans of old-style muscular action films will be after.
What the film lacks - apart from convincing dialogue - is a sense of humour...or even a real sense of wonder at how terrible nature can be.
If you like your comedy hilariously rude and crude then The Inbetweeners 2 is a must see film.
While there are some nicely gory moments, the film feels rather uninspired ...

While David Jung's debut film ticks all of the right genre boxes and works well technically it suffers from simply lacking originality and being another in a rather long list of found footage chillers.
Following on from his film Benny & Jolene, it marks out Adams as savvy talent able to bring out the best in his talented cast.
Japanese filmmaker Hitoshi Matsumoto delivers another delightfully skewed and oddball film.
This delightfully funny and smart family film certainly lives up to its title.
A resolutely left-field and refreshingly off-kilter drama.
Maria Gamboa's impressive debut feature, which had its world premiere at the Miami International Film Festival, tackles an old-fashioned -- good against evil -- with a whole lot of style

Peter Bogdanovich's love letter to the type of freewheeling sex comedy that was staple Hollywood fare in years gone by is a real pleasure, blessed with a series of smart and knowing performances and driven by a frothy sense of mainstream fun.
An impressively dour and dense new British drama, Blood Cells is a strikingly dark drama given heart and soul thanks to Barry Ward's suitably intense lead performance.
A visual and poetical treat that delves into lives, issues and traumas of residents of the grim (but oddly beautiful through Costa's camera) Lisbon neighbourhood of Fontainhas.
[A] rather enjoyable and tender film.
Absorbing and fascinating.
The film works well in terms of its visual and its immersive sound design, but not so much as a story about real people.
Robot Overlords is an engaging action romp that moves at a nice pace but eventually gets rather let down by effects efforts that are compromised by the film's low-budget origins.
An immersive delight.
A thoroughly enjoyable, delightfully honest movie, with a smattering of brilliantly witty lines.
A dreamy and quirkily twisted coming-of-age story.
A strangely compelling blend of gender-switching romance, drama and ghost story.
movie_title: Qissa: The Ghost Is A Lonely Traveller (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While there are times when it almost sinks under the weight of its sense of dark anger and depression, it is Leeshon Alexander fine performance that keeps it from sinking under.
An ambitious, thoughtful and provocative take on the Frankenstein story.
Gently challenging (it is the first of LaBruce's films without any sexually explicit content), beautifully shot and rather engaging at times.

Balancing magical realism with wistful drama, this tender film is given heart and soul thanks to the lead performances by Salma Samy and Menha Batraoui whose supportive friendship leads them on thoughtful journey.

An astutely made drama driven by impressive lead performances and tinged by an overwhelming sense of sadness.

A beautifully simple and stunningly elegant film.
The film is elegantly put together, and while not an easy one to bracket its sheer of unworldly unusualness makes it worth taking a look at.
Haunting and gently enthralling.

Sublimely violent

An over-cooked affair that lacks much needed wit and humour to go alongside its self-aware art intentions.
An absorbing and insightful delve into how the band defined the post-punk -- and consciously flamboyant UK -- music scene and went on to be an international phenomenon.
movie_title: Soul Boys Of The Western World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing and enjoyable.

A film that veers between amusing and absorbing through to grim and depressing.

A delicious blend of streetwise savvy and old-fashioned espionage motifs.

The film is rarely truly scary despite a smattering of chilling moments.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

Powerful, moving and provocative ...
movie_title: I Am Nojoom, Age 10 And Divorced (2014)

A wonderfully constructed film that takes a subtle-yet-angry swipe at the state of modern Russia.
An entertaining and absorbing film that interweaves several story strands and comes up with an enthralling portrait of a man whose powers may be fading but who still searches for answers.
A resolutely melodramatic film that feels engagingly old-fashioned as it revels in its lesbian love-triangle storyline.
An energetic, glossy and exciting New Zealand Maori action-adventure.

A lush cross-cultural romance all set against the dreamy backdrop of Manhattan, writer/director Victor Lewin's rather old-fashioned but generously witty film ticks all of the right boxes when it comes to its literary tale of an unlikely romance.
An astutely cold and compelling psychological drama.

While enjoyable in parts, its episodic pacing lets down the real-life story of a bold and remarkable woman.
A gentle charmer punctuated with a series of nicely judged performance and an increasing sense of magical realism.

Don't be put off with all of the mentions of violence. Yes, bloodletting is at the core of the movie, and the ending is as downbeat as the opening scenes. But, gosh, you know you have been to see a great film.
A slick and spiky drama that presents an alternate view of life for young people in Morocco.
A film that is reassuringly watchable, easy on the eye and does have more than a few moments to make you smile and laugh.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is an elegant and strikingly shot film that revels in a series of wonderfully shot locations ... and will likely enrapture fans of Malick's very individual style.

A wonderfully taut and thoughtfully unnerving drama ...

Spirals to an unconvincing climax that rather undoes the good work that has gone before.

While straight-forward in tone and structure, the film is admirably non-exploitative as it lays out the developing drama.

movie_title: Smash & Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Somehow the story can't quite tally with the rather familiar storyline.
A warm-hearted pleasure with a whole lot of soul, and effortlessly propelled forward by charming and compassionate performances by Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.

oe is a strikingly well rounded story of a hot-tempered man trying to deal with his demons and whose attempt to help a down-on-his luck teenager turns into a tender-but-tough protector but also takes him on a course towards violence.
Sion Sono's rousing, freewheeling, scattershot and ultimately astonishingly bloodthirsty film is a classic cult title that will keep midnight movie fans entertained.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There is a lot going on, but not a great deal happening.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

An enjoyably leftfield oddball comedy.

A delightfully odd film, but also an enjoyable one for film fans.
[Trace] works to a certain extent, with Danny Boyle drawing out game and smart performances from his three leads, James McAvoy, Vincent Cassel and (especially) Rosario Dawson.
In the end At Any Price lacks the emotional pay-off the story deserves.
An action-packed and swashbuckling cool fantasy adventure ...
Possibly one of the most joyously enjoyable films to screen in the Cannes competition -- especially for lovers of classic Hollywood cinema -- The Artist is a real pleasure.

Camp, kitsch and deliciously entertaining.

A bright, breezy, funny and beautifully presented film that will slug it out with Despicable Me 2 for the animated hit of summer award.

A blaze of thrilling sci-fi adventure, stunning special effects and - most importantly - further subtle development of a series of characters who are familiar and yet fresh at the same time.

Jeremy Lovering's chilling and gripping feature debut is an old-fashioned white-knuckle horror-thriller that revels in its sense of unsettling claustrophobic style as it tackles that primal fear of what might be lurking in the deep, deep, dark.
A pacy, funny romp through a very individual life.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

Will you be shocked, outraged, titillated? No, just bored.

Will you be shocked, outraged, titillated? No, just bored.

A charmingly played film about how life can offer up a second chance at the most unlikely of moments and how unexpected friendships can offer fresh perspectives.
A delightfully mannered and eccentric delight.
Wes Anderson's beautiful and thoroughly enjoyable The Grand Budapest Hotel sees the director deliver his best film.
[An] amiable and rather enjoyable dance comedy ...
Despite a few classy effects-driven moments it spirals to a rather flat and forgettable ending.

[An] exciting and entertaining romp that has enough twists and turns - and astute back-story - to keep film lovers happy, and enough city smashing devastation to impress genre fans.

An enjoyable - if rather unwieldy at times - adventure romp.

An engaging and nicely animated romp.

twee, and in gay fantasy land from the word go

two surreal films in one
a treasure, and more thrilling and suspenseful than most big action movies

You don't need to in any way qualify the positive assessment of this film. It's impressive work by any standards.
It is a movie packed with sublime performances and searingly memorable moments.
Sharknado 2: The Second One is bad, and that's good. Well, it's meant to be bad, in a good sort of way.
The reality is that HBO's Game Change makes a bad showing by arming game and gifted players with a weak and labored script.

From the first frame, it's clear that Jackie Robinson is a genuine labor of love. The warmly crafted two-part, four-hour PBS documentary from filmmaker Ken Burns positively glows with its admiration for the man and his accomplishments.

Washington and Pierce never yield the floor, giving Emmy-worthy performances that are at the heart of this film. You can see the difficulties in each of their faces in the glare of the fireworks exploding all around them.

Ortega's new song-and-dance take is intoxicating proof that you can do the Time Warp again. It's glowing evidence that you can go home again, as long you're being guided by a light burning at the Frankenstein place.
Befitting its subject, the documentary "Wait for Your Laugh" is a breezy and engaging whirlwind trip through the crowded life of a performer who pretty much embodies the show-business term "trouper."
The best way to soak in the experience is to let it wash over you like a shark-infested summer storm.
The movie manages to ask relevant spiritual questions.
Viciously funny!
Sure to strike a power chord with the millions of secretaries, office assistants and other white-collar grunts.
An unapologetically sloppy jumble of Roger Corman-style antics that could only hope to inspire their own drinking game.
The smart script by 23-year-old newcomer Helen Childress doesn't lose sight of the characters and the issues that affect them and other young adults.
Jones has crafted a natty narrative that, enhanced by Erin Nordstrom's editing, is filled with payoffs.
movie_title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Tanna touches on interesting issues of individual and collective responsibility, and the relative merits of revenge and restraint. And, purely as entertainment, it's very watchable.
A well shot and uniformly well acted film which draws the audience in by an increasingly tense and dramatic narrative.
Although it feels slightly generic at times, this reasonably entertaining thriller is made all the more intriguing due to the fact that it is inspired by real events.
It's strained, flat, laboured, repetitive, self-satisfied, largely unfunny, and has the drab and tacky look of a telemovie. Dr. Strangelove it ain't.
Despite an elegant and impressive visual style, the narrative of this slow-paced film is uninteresting and full of cliché.
New York, I Love You is a mild and a guilty pleasure, but it's a pleasure nonetheless.
An abysmal film: a buddy comedy with no jokes, implausible storylines and boring action scenes.
It boasts a crackerjack cast and a richly dense script, and scenes of inspired fantasy and hallucinatory nightmarish power.
It's neither inherently cinematic nor -- arguably -- particularly exciting.
While this often hilariously haphazard film draws you in, you're ultimately left trying to discern fact from fiction.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A must-see film with gripping performances and vivid evocation of urban warfare in Iraq.
While slightly patchy and too quirky, Ben Stiller is terrific in the lead role and the film is highly watchable, containing a handful of unforgettable moments.
he White Ribbon is unsettling, disturbing and enigmatic; it's often horrifying and occasionally eerily beautiful.
Fine performances anchor this entertaining film which provides real insight into the dynamics of power and politics.
Christian Bale steals the show with his unforgettable performance in this absorbing and bruising drama.
While an intriguing political thriller, it disappointingly lacks the atmosphere of Roman Polanski's previous masterpieces.
While tackling politically sensitive subject manner, this daring satire manages to offer both hilarity and poignancy.

The main problem with the film, though, is that it seems to assume that self-obsessed and charmless people are automatically interesting - just for being people. There's definitely a flaw in that logic.
Often uproariously funny, this cross-cultural comedy brims with sharp dialogue and its ideas are sensitive and intelligent without being heavy-handed.
In an early self-referential monologue, Greg says, "Who wants to see a movie about a kid who's stuck in middle school with a bunch of morons?" Who indeed?
It's not much more than a rattling good yarn -- but it certainly is that.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Could well have been a sub-Full Monty cliche-fest... overall it's a bit better than that, thanks to a raft of impressive performances, compelling and moving subplots, and scenes showing the economic and relationship costs of industrial action.
While it's well made and Danny Trejo is an amazing presence on screen, the sustained over-the-top violence becomes tiresome.
Well researched, and anchored by Rachel Weisz's impressive lead performance, this is a fascinating film that avoids the Hollywood epic route.
There's the usual pompous waffle implying that the very right to criticise makes America pretty damned heroic after all. But mostly it's just very forgettable.
While it opens with a promising start, this quickly becomes a vacuous and formulaic romantic comedy.
The beautiful scenery and glamorous lead actors can't make up for the increasingly absurd plot or flat performances.
Up In The Air is engaging, by turns witty and serious, unpredictable and surprisingly moving. Definitely recommended.
Brilliantly scripted and well acted, this painful and often funny drama avoids cliché and feels true to life.
Attractively shot, this quietly moving tale is marked by a handful of haunting moments.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An uneasy mix of comedy and ideas, which flatters both itself and its audience that it's smarter and wryer than it really is.
Alas, not for a minute does the viewer care about any character, though admittedly it's mildly diverting and intermittently funny -- and occasionally blackly or incongruously so.
Excellent performances from the entire cast don't make up for the fact that this film is mostly a highly forgetful, stylish, soap inspired story.
Despite an epic premise and the fine talent involved, the characters are under-written and the drama never soars.
Saccharine, cliched, groaningly predictable and -- in short -- utterly abysmal.
At a time when most other movies are boorishly brash, a film like this stands out precisely by being low key and modest.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At times, the film feels like it will collapse under the weight of its twists and excesses, but somehow it manages to hang together.
It's surprising, enthralling, intriguing, blackly droll, and a rattling good yarn.
A consistently powerful and harrowing true story -- and a well-told one. Simply watching it is somehow physically uncomfortable, but it's also rewarding.
Slow moving, torpid and melancholy...it's tearjerker material, but without the tears.
The special effects are spectacular enough here, and there are a few droll lines, but the net result is almost instantly forgettable.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Igor sends up all sorts of cliches, but -- by degenerating into a mawkish romance and a boring race against time -- it also becomes one.
If you've got a strong stomach, My Bloody Valentine 3D is a definite pleasure...albeit a guilty one, in the perversely stupid tradition of all good gore films.
It's wafer-thin and groaningly predictable, but it's also absurdly touching.
Truly original and very moving, with a hypnotic and elliptical quality all its own.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Notorious is a pretty standard biopic, and is probably largely compromised. If you've never seen Nick Broomfield's excellent 2002 doco Biggie And Tupac, you'd be better served hunting that down instead.
Blindness is not unmissable, and has awkwardly implausible moments, but it succeeds in sucking us into its peculiar world.
It's all humdrum and low key without any redeeming compositional elegance or symmetry.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially formulaic fare. Although Julia Roberts is quite good, the love scenes look exactly like what they are: famous people pretending.

Predictable, corny, schmaltzy, inane, unfunny, flat, sentimental and utterly fatuous. Most of the acting is bad, and none of the characters are interesting. Watching it is about as culturally rewarding as actually getting drunk, and less fun.
Summer Hours meanders along as a restrained mood piece, and is quite good and moving in parts, but it's just plain flat in others.
Skip the latest Hollywood trifle and see this instead.
Paris 36 is ill-conceived, predictable, overlong, flatly directed, over-acted, uninvolving, corny, riddled with trite music and smugly self-regarding. Not an unqualified success, one might say.
Defiance starts shakily but gets steadily more engrossing.
It's a predominantly bleak story, but never defeatist, and it stays with you.
Brilliantly made and utterly compelling from beginning to end.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's also mercifully free of the kind of phony pretensions to subversion and irreverence that weighed down, say, Robert Altman's The Player.
Some of the plot is implausible, yet the core ideas resonate richly, and the characters' behaviour is psychologically intriguing.
It hits the ground running, and - while never remotely innovative - manages to be unpredictable and labyrinthine enough to generally hold our attention.
Costa-Gavras scores a few telling points -- about the callous crassness of privileged tourists, for example -- but whatever his intentions, the end product is essentially a rattling good yarn.
An extraordinary performance from Benicio Del Toro anchors this long but gripping film based on a powerful true story.
Complete with an absurdist black humour and a bizarre collection of farcical set pieces, Louise-Michel is a hit and miss affair.
It features over sixty live performances, and there are a few pompous musicians and musicologists among the interviewees. But the engaging ones comfortably outnumber them...
What a film! Javier Bardem has always been impressive and convincing, but he's never been better than this.
An extraordinarily deft, well-pitched and multi-faceted film.
While it feels stagey at times and occasionally contrived, the acting is impressive and the story remains compelling throughout.
...a flawless masterpiece and essential viewing...
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: ...very sexually explicit, grotesquely violent and visceral, and extreme...
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ...consistently interesting...
...predictable andintermittently maudlin...
...touching, subtle,deftly andminutely observed...
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Just like a really good novel, it gets you so well acquainted with its characters that they start to feel like your friends, and you don't want it to finish because that will mean never seeing them again.
...a swashbuckling, exciting tale.
...watchable and diverting.
It's rather less than the sum of its parts, but some of those parts are magnificent.
...well acted, touching, both funny and serious, and above all deftly plotted and scripted.
...this is an odd, slow moving and only partly successful film.
This taut Iranian thriller recalls the work of Alfred Hitchcock, Claude Chabrol, and Brian De Palma.

Land Of Mine is... gripping, well-acted by all, and a good, strong tale well told. It's also that uncommon thing: a movie that touches on the theme of redemption without descending into bathos or inanity.
Mildly diverting.
Norman is pitched somewhere between comedy and character-driven drama, succeeding as neither.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ...the whole adds up to rather less than the sum of its parts.
"...a subtle and low-key affair about the great Swiss-Italian artist Alberto Giacometti."
...absolutely and emphatically not just another movie about World War II.
Greek provocateur Yorgos Lanthimus re-teams with Colin Farrell for another slice of absurdity.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... a very watchable, solid, frequently entertaining and sometimes touching true story.
The Wound has its moments, but they're pretty few and far between.
Imagine The West Wing minus all the wit ...
...a rattling good yarn with a complex plot and (rarity of rarities in mainstream cinema) a great ending.
... a tearjerker which won't necessarily jerk your tears.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Menashe Lustig's performance here is strong, in a subtly understated way, and there are a few - but very few - mildly emotionally resonant scenes.
...intermittently very funny...
Unmissable.
Though very much a respectful and admiring portrait of its subject, Gurrumul is not a hagiography.
Singularly winning mixture of irony, semi-parody and powerfully moving drama from the director of Jackie.
...a rollicking good yarn.
...touching, gently whimsical, grotesque and very strange.
...fast moving and passably exciting...
Excruciating.
Basically, it's Hollywood slush dressed up as American Gothic.
While this offers up the odd laugh, the continual banter grows tedious and wearying, and the whole affair seems pointless.
The emotional manipulation gets irritating though, and the characters seem more archetypal than real. They exist merely to prove a point.
Not for a minute is Fright Night either funny or scary. That's not too good in a comedy horror film.
Making superb use of the 3-D, and marked by Werner Herzog's idiosyncratic sensibilities, this contains enough captivating moments to make it a must-see.
...leaden...saccharine...
Boasting a first-rate screenplay and cast, and a wonderfully nostalgic atmosphere, this sometimes veers toward melodrama but always rings true.
A resonant, lyrical and beautifully realised cinematic experience.
A bleak but gripping retelling of a literary classic, which makes brave but effective use of its creative license.
It's a slight and modest flick that occasionally lapses into sentimentality, but it's original and nicely carried by the actors.
...just about enough memorable quotes, eloquence, personality, and pathos to divert even those of us with no interest in sport.

Latter day silent movies need not be cute or vacuous -- daring Canadian filmmaker Guy Maddin's avant-garde creations have proved that triumphantly -- but this one is a highly polished and clever bit of frippery.

There are constant twists and turns, eventually straining credulity, but there's also -- and typically for The Coens -- a salutary quorum of absurdist dialogue, black humour and wryly memorable exchanges.

Midnight In Paris is clever, watchable, mildly entertaining and quite amusing. Unfortunately -- after its initial gimmick -- it's also pretty predictable, and amounts to a lot less than the sum of its parts.
None of the stylistic elements serves to make for especially compelling viewing; it's overlong and occasionally irritating when it should be moving.
Whether you find this film revelatory, vindicating or provocative will rather depend on your preconceptions about Scientology -- or about religions in general. In any case, it's pretty gripping.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: ...all very silly and over the top...
...perfectly competently made...
...is watchable enough...

Eye In The Sky is sporadically sentimental, unrealistic, and overburdened with intrusive soundtrack music. But it gets you in, and it's suspenseful, claustrophobic, and a fairly unusual take on the counter-terrorism sub-genre.
Grimsby is a lot of fun in its determinedly tasteless way.

Despite the odd moment of dewy-eyed banality, it's really well made and researched, proffers a swag of interesting facts (some mindboggling, some touching, some inspiring, and some ghastly) and is definitely worth seeing.
Food is not an inherently cinematic subject, being fundamentally about the sense of taste rather than that of sight. But, in its own terms, this doco isn't too bad at all.
Terminus is slow moving and often underlit - presumably in the interests of ambience, but the murkiness gets monotonous and the creepy soundtrack music does little to alleviate the torpor.
This is a gripping film, and not to be missed.

It's mercifully "un-modernised" and pretty faithful to Charles M. Schulz' original comic strip, but it's also rather flat and not especially funny. And there's too much padding; it could just as well have been a short rather than feature-length.
The humour - there are quite a few good one-liners - and the warmth, the charm, the pathos, and the topic make it a pleasure.

Pride And Prejudice And Zombies stays watchable enough, because - for all its conceptual absurdity - it's mostly played straight rather than for laughs. It's not very good, but nor is it cringingly bad.
This Is Not a Film is a practical joke as much as it is a movie, and while it possesses a deadly serious undercurrent, what's most surprising is how witty the finished product is.

In a season unexpectedly full of quality family films, Arthur Christmas may have to fight for the attention it deserves, but if there was ever an example of a film that's a crowd-pleaser without talking down to its audience, this is it.
If this truly is Bela Tarr's final film, there's no arguing he bows out with something extraordinary that no other director could have imagined.
Its heart is still the relationship between a boy and his dog, and it still pulls at the heartstrings no matter how strongly you resist.

Tyler Perry's bid to reinvent himself like Bruce Willis or Matt Damon in Alex Cross is ultimately a failure, but if it's any consolation to him, he's hardly the only reason this film is not worth your time.

There's no arguing this is a remarkable story, and director Malik Bendjelloul tells it beautifully, creating a powerful sense of mystery and discovery even when we're tipped off to how the story ends.
Dave Grohl shares a lot of stories in Sound City, and what's most impressive is that for a first-time filmmaker he tells these tales remarkably well.
Philippe Falardeau's direction is a model of the notion that less is more, and this film is a treat well worth savoring.
Gere doesn't give Robert a remarkable amount of depth, but he certainly plays his damaged, agonized soul for all it's worth, even as the movie views him from a coolly removed distance.
It's clear Mother Nature is the real boss in Bakhtia, and Happy People: A Year in the Taiga documents a few men doing a wary pas de deux with her in a genuinely fascinating and intelligent fashion.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Eytan Fox and screenwriter Itay Segal have made this a truly universal story about a man who finds the courage to pursue the possibility of love again after heartbreak and loss.
A tale about love at its most terribly, backbreakingly difficult.

Corman's World sometimes plays more like a celebrity roast in which Corman's friends tell funny stories about him for 90 minutes with a lot of film clips thrown in, but those stories are often hilarious and enlightening.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a powerful, well-crafted film and a striking depiction of a side of growing up few filmmakers have tried to put on film. Fewer still have captured it with this sort of honesty and emotional gravity.

While Ceremony may not look or feel terribly original, Winkler has clearly learned a lot from his study of [Wes] Anderson's oeuvre, and he's made a comedy that's intelligent, stylish, and effective even when it's emulating someone else's work.
